Award.AwardTitle: Manhattan College Center for Preparing and Retaining STEM Scholars Teaching Engineering Principles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship capacity building project will investigate ways to promote and support engineering education for three groups of learners: i) engineers and engineering students, ii) students in middle and high schools - especially from underrepresented groups, and iii) current math and science majors pursuing teacher certification, who desire to be prepared to teach engineering principles to students in grades 6-12. Currently, there is little engineering in many teacher certification programs for individuals interested in becoming a STEM teacher; but the need has changed with the roll-out of the Next Generation Science Standards. Teachers are most often certified to teach math, science, or technology, but rarely have sufficient background to adequately teach engineering principles. Engineers, on the other hand, have expertise in engineering principles, but lack the knowledge and skills to effectively teach students.

To address the increasing demand for teachers qualified to teach the engineering concepts included in the Next Generation Science Standards, this project will produce skilled STEM educators through three newly developed programs; first a minor in education for students studying engineering. Second, a certificate in engineering education for STEM majors who are pursuing teacher certification, and third, a post-baccalaureate certificate in engineering education for engineering graduate students. The project will also provide professional development opportunities for current STEM educators. Finally, the project will select groups of university students to be trained to present hands-on workshops in local schools serving underrepresented groups with the intent of enticing these students to consider future studies in STEM related fields. The project will contribute to a transformative change in STEM educator preparation, while providing outreach services to high need schools and attracting these students to STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Manhattan College Center for Preparing and Retaining STEM Scholars Teaching Engineering Principles

As proposed, our project significantly addressed the needs of our country’s employment specifically the STEM pipeline. Report after report shows that the next generation of American employees will be unprepared for these jobs. This gap between demand and supply raised national concerns about producing STEM workforce and equally important STEM educators.

The purpose of our program was to produce a skilled workforce ready to teach engineering and math, science, and technology for K-12 students. We offered an innovative program to capture the interest and passion of teachers who wished to pursue greater learning in STEM fields where none exist with emphasis on engineering and imaginative and powerful teaching about engineering to students.  In addition, we included a unique opportunity for engineers who have a passion to serve as engineering educators in our K-12 educational system.

Teachers from local schools serving high-needs populations collaborated with engineering professors in learning principles of engineering and then designing lesson plans that were taught to K-12 students. The work between the teachers and the professors resulted in more than 30 STEM integrated lesson plans that are available at http://star.manhattan.edu/en/star-pd/lesson-plans . 

Additionally, Manhattan College Engineering STAR program offered an innovative, high quality and affordable education to its talented and enthusiastic students to prepare them as skilled STEM educators to teach in grades K-12 education systems. We collaborated with high need schools, schools that have diverse challenges in helping their students meet academic success including, but not limited to, students with special needs and from low income families as well underrepresented minorities.

Two programs were established to offer opportunities for engineering students to attain a certification in education and for education students to explore engineering principles. These programs developed seven courses to create the education concentration and the engineering concentration.

In addition, undergraduates in engineering and education were invited to apply for admission into the STAR Ambassadors program, a program in which participants received formal training in communication including: group dynamics, communication/interpersonal skills, resourcefulness, leadership and presentation. These Ambassadors worked together in designing presentations for students in high-need schools on concepts of STEM including a hands-on activity with emphasis on engineering applications. These Ambassadors made presentations to more than 700 K-12 grade students. In addition, they have created a STEM portable library that allows them to transport materials to local schools to further build an interest in STEM education at earlier ages.

            As a result of our multiple activities, a partnership was established between the School of Engineering, the School of Education and Health, as well as teacher and school partnerships to continue addressing the need for narrowing the gap between supply and demand in producing STEM workforce and STEM educators.  Available lesson plans, student presentations, and a lending library have become resources for local schools with additional on-line resources found at http://star.manhattan.edu/ .
